newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Commission expects French information on C.Lyonnais rescue.
newsitem.headline: Commission expects French information on C.Lyonnais rescue.

text.p: The European Commission on Tuesday was expecting France to provide it with new information concerning a rescue plan for embattled French bank Credit Lyonnais.
Commission sources said European Union executive had not yet received any oral or written plan from Paris to soften the terms of a huge restructuring plan approved in July 1995.
But the information as expected to be transmitted to Brussels later in the day.
One source said it was evident that a new request would have to be filed as the bank struggled to free itself from the burden imposed by the Commission in last year's rescue plan.
The bank is due to give half-year results on Thursday which are expected to show that it has plunged back into the red unless the rescue plan in changed retroactively to last Janaury.
Competition Commissioner Karel Van Miert was to give a news conference on the issue on Wednesday.
Last year, the Commission approved a French bail-out plan dubbed as one of the largest rescue in the banking history. It permitted payment of a maximum of 45 billion French francs in aid.
In return, the Commission told the bank it had to grant a loan below maret rate to a state-backed vehicle to which 135 billion francs worth of loss-making assets were transferred.
Any revision to the 1995 plan, and particularly to the conditions imposed on Credit Lyonnais, must be approved by the Commission. REUTER
